It’s burgeoning, it’s blooming#Pictured is Joseph Goss, co-owner of Rum Barber on Kersland Street.For At Largltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgte feature by Lorne Jltspan classtruncate-full-screengtackson for The Herald Magazine.Photograph by Colin MearnsDOUGLAS Timmins stood at the door of the nightclub he managed in Melrose Place and gazed up into the Hollywood Hills. The Pacic Ocean lapped lazily nearby. It was the only lazy thing in LA. Everything  was go, go, go.Including Douglas, bracing himself for the night ahead. Would Whitney Houston slink into the club  Possibly. Shersquod been before. Those fresh-faced celebrity brats would certainly be coming. The Beverley Hills  kids couldnrsquot stay away. Or the gang from Friends.As Douglas stood there, Hollywood happy, Calornia content, his thoughts kept sneaking away from him. They clambered over the Hollywood sign, swam the pacic ocean, thumbed a lt to Glasgow. And came to rest in the West End of that faraway city.Douglas Timmins, now , has led an extraordinary le. He has seen it all, been it all. Survived more scrapes than a schoolboyrsquos knee. Travelled extensively, too. But Glasgowrsquos West End always draws him back.ldquoFor a Glasgow boy like me, living and working in Hollywood was a dream come true, Douglas tells me.ldquoEven so, every now and again that feeling would come over me. Irsquod realise I was thousands of miles from home. All of a sudden it seemed a really, really long way. I missed my friends. I missed the West End of Glasgow.The West End is where I bump into Douglas, a legendary figure in these parts. Hersquos been a fixture here, on and off, since the late s, when he worked as a barman at a local drinking den. There have been many jobs, and many Douglases, since those days. Hersquos a fascinating group of people. And a good person to chat toyou truly want to understand the bohemian enclave that is Glasgowrsquos West End.This part of town has always been a little bit dferent. The people are a puzzle to the uninitiated. They march to their own drum. Booze and womanisingThe West Endrsquos unique culture was recently celebrated when Time Out magazine voted it the coolest place to live in Scotland.Which brings me back to Douglas, who is certainly cool in that quirky, quixotic way that can only be experienced in this part of town.His personality is too huge, and barnacled in eccentricities, to fit in comfortably anywhere . With his voice like tractor tyres crunching through pebbles, and a face more weathered than a Mount Rushmore President, he seems to have sauntered straight out of a Damon Runyon short story. Douglas Timmons is a Guys and Dolls sorta guy.And, like so many West Enders, he has tales to tell. Raised in Mount Vernon, he hitched up his wagon and followed the trail west after hearing from a friend that glamorous Swedish blondes were in much abundance in this part of town.No Swedish blondes did Douglas find, though he stuck around anyway, and became a settler. Douglas has enjoyed a iety of jobs. He trained as a tailor, though left after a member of the Calton Tong, who frequented the shop where Douglas worked, threatened him with a kne and demanded the contents of the till.ldquoHe happened to be standing next to a hatch that led down to this cavernous cellar, says Douglas. ldquoSo I just pushed him down. He broke his legs and all his mates came back to get me. I decided it was an excellent time to leave that particular job.A wide range of occupations followed. Douglas worked briefly as a journalist. He inserted free gts in comics. He worked in the metal industry, where he met David Murray, a close friend. He set up a modelling agency, and hired a young unknown called Carol Smillie.He also opened a West End bar and revelled in booze and womanising. Thus his dosh was squandered, and he nearly lost his le, too, when an unforgiving ex hired hitmen to bump him off.ldquoYou always think plotters are intelligent, Douglas muses. ldquoBut not necessarily. What should be straight forward and simple becomes complicated, and they talk everything to death. They go and tell somebody, who tells you. And you stop it.And how did Douglas prevent this attempt on his le ldquoLetrsquos just say there was a pavement debate with the chap who arranged my assassination, says Douglas, enigmatically.It was another failed romance that led Douglas to flee to America in the early s, where he found employment as a gym instructor. world, and had only recently stopped boozing and smoking fags.Next he worked in nightclubs, as a bouncer and manager. He even got mixed up in the LA riots, and, at one point, worked as a bodyguard for a Russian billionaire who lived near Bob Dylanrsquos Malibu pad.ldquoHe was a legend for not paying his bills, says Douglas. ldquoAnd people would come after him. So he handed me a pump-action shotgun and a Smith  Wesson . I told him I didnrsquot have a license to use guns. I didnrsquot even have a licence to be in America.Eventually Douglas ed to Glasgow and his beloved West End, where he still enjoys meeting new people, and immersing himself in the local culture. ldquoThe West End is blossoming, itrsquos burgeoning, itrsquos blooming, he says. ldquoAnd thatrsquos what I love. Whenever I travel away, I have to come back.I know what Douglas means.Opium denEven the local second-hand bookstore, Voltaire  Rousseau, is a joy to visit. Imagine Waterstones after an earthquake, and yoursquoll begin to understand the special ambience that permeates VR.In Waterstones the books stand rigid and regimented. In VR they sprawl and lounge and hunker in heaps.These mounds of literature donrsquot demand to be read, they yearn to be bagged, like a Munro. While browsing in this Aladdinrsquos bazaar I spot a voluptuous and decadent cushion lying atop a towering babel of ancient Bibles. You can almost imagine a debauched aristocrat resting his head upon such a pillow in some s opium den.A moment later that same pillow yawns, stretches and purrs. It turns out to be a cat who lives in the shop. His name is B.B. Just another West End hipster.Animals are definitely as exotic as their owners in this neck of the woods. As are their tastes. A local pet store sells Pawseco lsquowinersquo for cats and dogs.Even the hairdressers arenrsquot content to merely snip the fuzzy tops of customerrsquos heads.Joseph Goss, who owns Rum Barber, tells me hersquos also a filmmaker.He, and his business partner, Paul Montgomery, have set up their own YouTube channel, where they create wacky hairdressing content with special effects.They already have over twenty-two thousand subscribers, many in America, where their fanbase is growing rapidly.Such a buzzThis can-do creativity and ability to think beyond borders is very much a West End aesthetic.ldquoWersquore trying our best to be media stars, laughs Joseph. ldquoOur films arenrsquot exactly James Cameronesque. But they are fun little quirky things that hopefully make us stand out from the crowd.Standing out from the crowd is exactly what the Ubiquitous Chip on Ashton Lane has been doing since opening in .In many ways itrsquos the epicentre of the West End, a boho bar and restaurant where the edgier boys and girls hang out, hob knob and raise hell. Gabriel Etchells is marketing assistant at the Chip. The twenty-two-year-old graduated from Robert Gordon University in Aberdeen last year. Now settled in the West End, the area reminds her of her days and nights hitting the textbooks. ldquoWith Glasgow University nearby, itrsquos very student orientated, she says. ldquoBut the West Endrsquos unique because itrsquos such a mix of young and old. You have the history, the culture, the art and music. Then therersquos the young people coming in, shaking things up, making their presence felt.ldquoIrsquod say the West End is always flowing, yet never moving. Itrsquos such a unique place. It really is a buzz to live here.

title: david-suchet-feel-like-outsider-country
story: He treasures the trinkets because of the man they used to belong to: Hercule Poirot, the detective Suchet played on television for  years. When the great actor finally relinquished the role after filming every single story that Agatha Christie wrote, the television company gave him the mementos of his time as Poirot and he says he likes to keep them close by. He also has Poirotrsquos cane. ldquoEvery time I hold that cane, he says, ldquoI can feel him.The cane is particularly special, says Suchet, because of the powers it had when he was playing Poirot it worked like a kind of talisman, a way for him to transform himself from British actor to Belgian detective. Just before he started filming, he would get the cane out and walk around the garden like Poirot, quick, little steps. He would also speak out loud like him and try to look at the world through his eyes, a man who liked order, symmetry and detail. If the pictures on the walls of his house werenrsquot straight, he would straighten them. If the eggs he had for breakfast werenrsquot precisely the same size, he would disapprove. And once in character, he would keep it up and maintain the accent and performance even when he was speaking to his we.To people who arenrsquot actorsthis might sound a bit weird, but Suchet was utterly committed and methodical when it came to playing Poirot. When he first got the part, he went through the novels and listed every single detail of Poirotrsquos habits and gestures. He also made a list of ways in which he was similar to, and dferent from, the detective and the similarities were striking. Occasionally in real le ndash sans moustache, sans Belgian accent, sans everything ndash Suchetrsquos words and phrases can even sound like Poirotrsquos.Take, for example, the moment we get talking about nostalgia and regrets. ldquoWe do not know the webs we spin, he says, ldquoand itrsquos only when you look back that you say, look at how that led to thatrsquo.Itrsquos the kind of thing Poirot might say while summing up the facts at the end of one of his cases, but itrsquos also how Suchet likes to look at his le. We humans donrsquot know what wersquore spinning as we go through le, he says, but then we turn around and see the shape of what wersquove been building.And so, over coffee on the bank of the Thames, we follow some of the threads of silk back through Suchetrsquos le and find the man who taught him how to feel emotions and the father he was never close to. We also find his faith in God and his fear of death and his feeling, always, of being an outsider and of being on the edge. Poirot also fades in and out as we talk, pointing out, with his usual knack for being right, how alike he is to man who played him.But first, Suchet, , wants to do something. He picks up the camera he carries with him almost everywhere. Wersquore sitting right by Tower Bridge but Suchet isnrsquot interested in such London clicheacutes. Hersquos more interested in the salt cellar and glass on the table in front of us. He points the camera. His forehead tightens, his forefinger slides on the focus. There. Done. ldquoI just wanted to capture the light from outside on the glass, he says. ldquoWhat nature had done to it. Oh, look. The momentrsquos gone. Itrsquos stopped. Itrsquos gone.I ask where he gets this passion for photography, which forms the basis of his new book Behind the Lens, and he tells me about one of the most important threads of silk in his le: his grandfather, Jimmy Jarche. Jarche was a newspaper photographer and Suchet particularly remembers the smell of the Syrian pipe tobacco he used to smoke. He also remembers the way Jimmy behaved with him as a boy: he held him a lot, Suchetrsquos arms wound round his grandfatherrsquos neck. Suchet could also talk to Jimmy in a way that he never could to his father.ldquoMy father was a man of his time, says Suchet, who has two adult children with his we Shelia. ldquoHe was of his type. He was South African and arrived in this country as an outsider and became an insider because he became this brilliant surgeon. But he developed an Edwardian attitude and part of his personality was that he couldnrsquot open up. He was closed emotionally, quite unlike me. Suchet says he finds it easy to love he enjoys loving.The relationship with his father was always a problem though ndash in fact, Suchet says they never really had what you could call a father son relationship it also meant Suchetrsquos father struggled to express his pride in his son when he started to have success as an actor. ldquoHe would show off photographs of his children in his office and say how proud he was, but never to us. But I was lucky to have Jimmy who allowed me to have an emotional relationship with an older man who guided me in my le.He tells me a story to show what he means. If his grandfather saw a beggar on the street, he says, he would sit down next to him and have a chat and askthere was anything he could do and Suchet says he still feels the influence of that attitude today. As we talk, people approach the table and ask for selfies and autographs and Suchet is friendly and smiling, always.ldquoJimmy is why I donrsquot hold myself above anybody, he says. ldquoIf Irsquom well known and famous, thatrsquos happened to me but I donrsquot see myself as anybody dferent from anybody . Wersquore all travellers wersquore on the same escalator and wersquore all going to drop off at the top. If wersquore lucky, of course. Some people drop off half way through.Which leads to the other great influence Jimmy has had on Suchet. He tells me that, after his grandfather died, he carried on speaking to Jimmy in his head. And then something weird happened. Suchet was lying in the bath in America one day, in the s, thinking about Jimmy when a thought struck him: Why am I thinking like this, when I donrsquot even believe in an afterle  Jimmyrsquos not there. Which got him thinking about the afterle a bit more. He bought a Bible and read Paulrsquos letter to the Christians in Rome and began the process that led to him finding his faith.It took a long time ndash around  years in fact, which reflects one of the similarities between Suchet and Poirot: their methodical approach to work and le. After that moment in America, Suchet researched religion and read and read and read until he could get to what he calls a point of hope and mystery.ldquoI canrsquot have blind faith, he says. ldquoBut Irsquom comfortable to live within a mystery. We are only comfortable with a calculator. We need clear answers. I canrsquot give you a clear answer I canrsquot even persuade you. I wouldnrsquot want to persuade you. Interestingly, Suchet says his grandfather was an atheist. ldquoBut in a sense he was the epitome of faith. Loving and caring about other people and giving and being generous with himself.Suchet recognises that this belief and his faith make him a little dferent in a country thatrsquos more likely to believe in Richard Dawkins The God Delusion than The Bible, but he has become used to the status of outsider, in his own country and even in his own profession. He is not a great fan of theatricality, he says, nor is he a great socialite and doesnrsquot much like theatrical parties. ldquoIrsquom always on the edge, he says. ldquoBecause therersquos a lot of me thatrsquos quite introvert. I donrsquot enjoy that side of my profession. I feel awkward in it.Suchetrsquos heritage has also made him feel dferent in other ways. ldquoI donrsquot know why, but I relate to the outsider, maybe because my blood line is Lithuanian Jew, brought up third generation British, he says. Itrsquos also made him aware of how Britain, and London in particular, welcomes, or doesnrsquot welcome, incomers.ldquoI love London, he says, ldquobut I canrsquot bear hearing people say, lsquooh, itrsquos so full of foreignersrsquo. Do you know why itrsquos so full of foreigners  Because everybody wants to be here and itrsquos a funny thing: everybody that comes here become Londoners, they fall in love with it. We welcome people. Itrsquos the only moment in our conversation where Suchet gets angry.But here, too, there are similarities with Poirot ndash Christiersquos great detective was an immigrant, a Belgian living in London and sometimes coming up against thoughtlessness and racism. What are the other parallels  Both men are fastidious ndash Suchet says he would sometimes drive the costume department barmy with his attention to detail. Both men also despise chaos ndash before he starts a job, Suchet has to start with a completely cleared desk. ldquoI will feel chaos deep within me, he says. ldquoI have to get rid of it, because it affects me. I have to feel calm and ordered, deep inside.We shouldnrsquot exaggerate the similarities of course, but Suchet does talk about an incident that seems to emphasise them ndash for viewers and Suchet himself. It happened when one of the Poirot films was being made in Hastings. There was a break in filming and Suchet had gone for a walk. He was in full costume and standing in an ordinary street. Suddenly a little old lady came up the hill towards him. She stopped. ldquoOoohh. Ohhhh. Hello, Mr Poirot, she said. Suchet didnrsquot know quite what to do so said ldquoHello, madame as Poirot. lsquoOooohh, ooohh,rsquo she went. lsquoI watch you all the time, Mr Poirot. What you doing here, though  There ainrsquot been a murder, has there rsquoSuchet replied, lsquoNo, madame. There has been no murder, not here in Hastings.rsquo lsquoWhat are you doing here then rsquo she asked. lsquoI am on holiday,rsquo I replied, lsquoI am en vacances.rsquo lsquoOh, thatrsquos nice. Lovely. And off she went.Itrsquos a moving little story and revealing about Suchet. He says he didnrsquot want to disillusion the old lady but he was also deep in character when she turned up right in the middle of the serious business of being the Poirot that Agatha Christie created. ldquoThatrsquos my reason for being an actor, he says. ldquoTo serve the writer.It can make it hard to move on to the next stage though, particularly with Poirot. ldquoI got to know Poirot after  stories and  years and Irsquove been in nearly every situation with him in le and I know how he reacts and Irsquove reacted with him because hersquos me. So I know him as well as I would know any best friend. And he dies. Hersquos gone. Irsquom grieving. Irsquove lost a friend. I can bring him back but only in my memory, like Jimmy.Which brings us, via the web of le, to the other metaphor that Suchet used earlier: the escalator, the one that wersquore all and the one that eventually ends. Suchet tells me that he likes to go on retreat to find peace and quiet, but he says there are still little and big fears and concerns that bug him. He worries, for example, about what he calls the dangerous society we live in ndash dangerous because more and more people seem obsessed with fame. You have to be careful not to live your le for other peoplersquos praise, he says.But Suchet also worries about more personal things. In the old days, he says,there was something on his mind, his grandfather Jimmy would tell him to come and sit with him. Often, Suchet wouldnrsquot know what to say but Jimmy would tell him: it doesnrsquot matter, just sit with me. These days, Suchet has his family and his faith.So how does he feel about the escalator of le  ldquoIrsquom frightened of death, he says, ldquoand nobody has come back since Christ to tell me whatrsquos beyond. You get people who say, my faith makes me convinced and I say to them, yoursquore so lucky. But he tries to rationalise the fear. Wersquore all on the same escalator, he says, sweeping his arm round the room. ldquoJust accept it, he says, ldquoDonrsquot worry about worrying.Behind the Lens: My Le by David Suchet is published by Constable at pound. David Suchet is raising awareness for the UK charity Tuberous Sclerosis Association which funds research into Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, a rare genetic condition that affects around  million people worldwide. For more information visit www.tuberous-sclerosis.org.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: ONE of the highlights of Tory conference was the wit and wisdom of Scottish Secretary Alister lsquoIrsquom all rightrsquo Jack. The hunting-shooting-fishing toff revealed Scottish Tory MPs had been ldquobrought into line on a no-deal Brexit, suggested sending gunboats to defend passing fish, and called for a Union-themed bank holiday to replace a ldquoleft wing one. Most folk think he meant May Day. We suspect the tweedy old Grinch meant Christmas.Music manIMALLRIGHT was only rivalled in comic potential at the conference by Peter Chapman. As Unspun first revealed, the crusty north east fermer turned MSP has made a CD of himself belting out Sangs  Poems in the Doric. Top tunes include ldquoThe Ploo, Pan Loaf, and Miser Toonrsquos Pig. So proud is he of his talents, Unspun hears he was eagerly pressing copies on unwitting delegates, regardless of their appetite. Oh, Manchester, so much to answer for.WhaddyacallhimANOTHER of the Scottish Toriesrsquo northeast odd squad is Holyrood man of mystery Tom Mason. Last year, after he was called to speak, the list MSP was immortalised by Nicola Sturgeon who declared: ldquoTom Mason  Whorsquos Tom Mason  This week at FMQs, Mr Mason finally made a name for himself by referring to the Presiding Officer as the Returning Officer. ldquoMy apologies, but I was caught up in the by-election in Bridge of Don in Aberdeen.Natty as fruitcakesJUST how bad are things in the Lanarkshire SNP  The partyrsquos most dysal outpost has outdone itself this week on the feuding front, as rivals slog it out for the Westminster candidacy in Coatbridge. Now Unspun hears a leading member of the lsquoMonklands McMafiarsquo faction actually backed Labour in a recent council byelection because they hated the SNP colleagues involved in the fight. We shall refrain from naming the MSP in question.Owl troubleTALKING of Labour, we see new Scottish party press boss Conrad lsquoSmoothrsquo Landin has been tidying up his Twitter profile. ldquoPrint journalist by trade, now a press officer. Proud GMB member, says the former Scotland editor of the Morning Star. We much preferred his old one, in which he described himself as a humble ldquoowl and fox enthusiast. We trust he finds Scottish Labour red in tooth and claw enough for his liking. Just watch out for those talons.Conceited  Moi ALSO trying to get elected to Westminster is former SNP MP Michelle Thomson, who has taken a run at East Lothian. When a local newspaper reported her ambitions, it mentioned she was once investigatedfor alleged mortgage fraud. ldquoThis is a tired refrain, she drawled on Twitter. ldquoWouldnrsquot it just be more fitting to say well done  Ok. Well done on a snooty response to the media for simply reporting the facts. Great PR plan. Happy now Button pushersGAFFE of the week belonged to the Scottish Government. After a six-year build up, it published its final position on fracking a day early by mistake online. Cue a dish of humble pie with the Presiding Officer, as Holyrood should have been told first. Unspun hears a junior staffer had been updating a file on fracking and naturally pressed lsquoSaversquo when prompted. Alas, this turned out to mean lsquoSave and publishrsquo, confirming the timeless adage that in government itrsquos iniably one per cent conspiracy and % cock-up.

title: charles-livingstone-hope-best-prepare-worst
story: For many businesses who have been living under a shadow of uncertainty since the  referendum though, there remains much to be resolved ndash and for the moment no-deal exit is still a possibility. ldquoOur advice to clients at the moment is that itrsquos prudent to plan on the basis that there will not be a deal, says Charles Livingstone, a partner at Brodies LLP and an expert on legislation and regulation issues. ldquoAnd until there is some other development that remains the path along which we are travelling.Prime Minister Boris Johnson meets EU Commission President Jean-Claude Junker last month.While waiting to hearthere is signicant progress by the time the European Council meets in the middle of this month, he adds, it is still imperative to prepare for the eventuality of no-deal. ldquoThat is still the default outcome as even under the Benn Act passed by Parliament, any extension of Article  needs the agreement of all the other EU member states.Brodies is the only independent Scottish law firm with a presence in Brussels and has been helping its clients manage risk through its Brexit Advisory Group. ldquoThat draws expertise together from across the firm to form lsquoa one stop shoprsquo for informed legal advice on the issues raised by Brexit, says Livingstone, who is co-head of the group.The potential pathways and options for which every business should be planning have narrowed, says Livingstone. ldquoBy October  there are only four things that can happen: there will be Brexit with a deal there will be a no-deal Brexit there will be an extension of the Article  deadline or the UK will revoke its Article  notice ndash and while there are lots of permutations within each of those outcomes and dferent ways they could be reached, at its most basic only one of those four things can happen ndash there is no fth outcome. One positive is that it is now somewhat easier to focus on a smaller number of potential outcomes rather than being overwhelmed by the sheer number of iables.The challenges posed by a no-deal Brexit will have an obvious impact on manufacturing companies that are engaged in import and export with the EU. ldquoWe are dealing with a lot of very niche queries at the moment, related to specic areas and sectors of business, says Livingstone. ldquoThere is clearly a lot of interest in immigration matters and settled status for employees and family members who are already living in Scotland but beyond that there is no one principal theme that is dominating the agenda, the queries we are receiving are all quite business specic.Larger clients, he points out, have the obvious advantage of possessing the personnel and financial resources to cope with that and the more heavily regulated businesses have already done their preparation some time ago. ldquoMany of these companies who already operate outside the EU and have a presence there will have import export procedures in place and while they would see a dference in volume, the procedures would not necessarily be substantially dferent from what they are already used to.It is the smaller companies and those in the SME sector who may not have done enough planning, and businesses who only import from, or export to, the EU who would see the most change. ldquoThese businesses will have to become familiar with procedures that will be new to them, he says.For many the administrative burden seems daunting but Livingstone stresses that there are some major areas that Brodies is encouraging clients to focus on. ldquoIn terms of importing and exporting the main area to address is Economic Operators Registration and Identicationnumbers. This is one of the major things that businesses can take control of. If a business only deals with import or export declarations in the UK, with a customer client completing the equivalent declaration on the EU side of the border, it will only need a UK EORI number andregistered for UK VAT, a number should already have been assigned by HMRC.However,the firm is responsible for completing both the export declaration as goods leave the UK, as well as the import declaration when the goods are imported into the EU,it will need both a UK and an EU EORI number. ldquoThe need to have two EORI numbers in certain circumstances, says Livingstone, ldquois not an issue that has been very visible to businesses.The UK Government, he says has published a series of ldquotechnical notices providing guidance on how to prepare for a no-deal Brexit, including  notices on importing and exporting. The notice on existing EU trade deals with non EU countries states the UK Governmentrsquos intention to replicate those EU arrangements in bilateral UK agreements.ldquoThe plan is for the status quo with non-EU countries to be maintained through any transitional period agreed with the EU, but in a no-deal scenario trade with third countries would default to World Trade Organizationrules until a replacement bilateral agreement could be established. Businesses trading with third countries on the basis of EU agreements, whether directly or via their supply chains, should carefully consider how changes to trade rules would impact them .And while some businesses, particularly in the SME sector, are possibly assuming another extension to Article  on the basis of some of the current rhetoric and media reporting around the Benn Act, Livingstone stresses that Parliament can instruct the UK Government but cannot dictate the EUrsquos response. ldquoSo our message to clients is that this is not a situation where Parliament, or any one party, is entirely in control of what will happen.ldquoBusinesses should be aware of the challenges and perhaps the opportunities of Brexit that are specic to them ndash what they are exposed to and what are their sectorrsquos risks in relation to any exit, he says. In short, try to avoid surprises.The right to move goods freely could end this month.Exporting and importing may become much more complicatedIN the event of a no-deal Brexit, the right to move goods freely between the UK and the EU would fall away as of pm on October st, , and trade would revert to World Trade Organizationrules.As a result,you trade with the EUyou may have to comply with the more onerous customs, excise and VAT procedures and rules that already apply to goods traded with non-EU countries ndash in a no-deal scenario the UK and EU will treat goods moving between them in the same way they currently treat trade with those countries .Full import and export declarations, and separate safety and security declarations, may therefore be required.An EORI numberis currently required to trade goods with non-EU countries, and so will also be required to trade with the EU in a no-deal scenario .In a no-deal scenario a range of goods would become liable to tarfs.For goods exported to the EU, the relevant customs duty set out in the EUrsquos Common Customs Tarf would apply.Goods coming into the UK from the EU would become subject to a new UK tarf.This would include imports from the EU .If you export to or import from non-EU countries, you should be considering whether those are among the  or so countries that have a free trade agreement with the EU, andso how the UKrsquos status under that agreement might be affected by Brexit.In any transition period the intention would be for the EU, UK and third countries to continue to act asthe UK remains an EU Member State. If there is no deal the UK Government is aiming to put bilateral agreements in place with the relevant countries as quickly as possible and has already signed a number of ldquocontinuity trade agreements.However, there is likely to be a gap between Brexit and some agreements entering into force, and not all agreements are on track to be lsquorolled overrsquo in time or at all, which would mean trade with the relevant countriesreverting to the same WTO terms as UK-EU trade.Manufacturers should conduct reviews to keep goods flowingIF you are a UK manufacturer of goods that are subject to EU-wide standards you should review whether your existing conformity assessments and certications will continue to be recognised in the EU. You should also review whether you will need to obtain separate UK certication to cover use of your products in the UK.UK bodies approved by the EU for certication purposes will no longer be recognised by the EU, so in a no-deal scenario the results of conformity assessments carried out by those bodies will no longer be recognised either.Products assessed by UK bodies will therefore no longer be able to be placed on the EU market unless they have been reassessed and re-marked by a body that remains EU-recognised, or the manufacturerrsquos files are transferred to an EU-recognised body pre-Brexit. CE marking based on self-declaration of conformity will still be possible, including when exporting to the EU.More detail is available in the EUrsquos preparedness notice and accompanying QA document on industrial products .The UK Government has also published its own guidance on placing manufactured goods on the EU internal market . Meanwhile, the UK Government plans to introduce a new UK mark for new products, to indicate compliance with UK standards .Products that have a European CE marking will still be able to be placed on the UK market, though that option will be time-limited for products certied post-Brexit, and so a duplicate UK marking may ultimately be required.This article appeared in The Herald on the th October For more information please visit www.brodies

title: firm-cash-bid-make-plant-based-construction-material
story: IndiNature, based in Edinburgh, needs pound. million to build the technology that will produce the material made from UK-grown hemp and flax.Scott Simpson, managing director, has been developing the innovative material for three years and the company aims to be operational by the end of next year.Mr Simpson believes the potential impact of the insulation, which is bonded using a natural binder he invented, is ldquoabsolutely gigantic.He said: ldquoThe construction sector takes about half of global natural resources at the moment and we solve that problem by using renewable resources- annual crops.The industry also accounts for  per cent of global carbon emissions through the manufacture, transport and construction of building materials as well as operational emissions.And at least  per cent of Scotlandrsquos overall waste is produced by the sector, according to Zero Waste Scotland.Mr Simpson said: ldquoWe solve all those problems with our product. We save carbon because we make a really high quality energy efficient system but the biggest impact is that we knock about a quarter of the construction carbon footprint off the average UK house because we store more carbon in the products than the amount that was needed to make them.IndiNaturersquos production is estimated to use around an eighth less energy than standard glass and rock wool insulation, and their use of naturally carbon storing crops that pull carbon dioxide from the air makes their material almost carbon neutral.The industrial hemp and flax crops are naturally resilient too, taking unexpected weather iations such as flooding in their stride.Currently the supply chain is based in the north of England but Scottish farmers who want to revive the traditional crops previously used to supply the navy with anchor ropes and rigging are in talks with the company.It was while renovating his own home with eco materials that Mr Simpson discovered that not all sustainable building products are created equally.After importing apparently eco insulation, he noticed that it was bound with petro-plastics, negating the companyrsquos environmental credentials.He said: ldquoI thought I was doing the eco thing but when I read the text-sheet it said it used petro-chemicals and it was eye wateringly expensive so I thought, why donrsquot we do this here in Scotland With a background in community development, Mr Simpson worked in housing and saw people living in ldquoterrible conditions.He said: ldquoHouses were damp, [people] couldnrsquot afford to heat them, there was black mould and fuel poverty.It was during a masters in Sustainable Architecture that Mr Simpson started developing the materials he now uses to produce the insulation he thinks will revolutionise the construction industry.He said: ldquoI thought,you can solve the built environment problem, you can solve a lot of problems.ldquoIf you know to design the built environment in a holistic way with sustainable materials that will have a huge impact on peoplersquos health and reduce the impacts on the environment.A site had been secured in Hawick to build their first factory, close to their farm supply chain. As well as working with Scottish farmers in the future, IndiNature hope to boost employment in the area.The insulation can be retro-fitted into homes and businesses, allowing for current social housing developments to benefit from the technology. Mr Simpson is in talks with local authorities, contractors and big firms who ldquoknow they need to move into the sector.The company has plans for expansion with their global replication model that will build factories overseas.Mr Simpson said: ldquoI used to be involved with building nice little bespoke homes for wealthy people which is great but there was nothing being done on an industrial scale.ldquoGlobally we aim to be a pound million plus business but with one factory wersquore looking at a poundm turnover."

title: property-developer-says-giving-dream-build-specialist-dementia-home-bute
story: The property developer and her husband, Ian, purchased the seafront plot south-east of Rothesay in , and was granted planning permission for her Ascog Park project a year later.However, the land remains empty and Mrs Woollcott says she is on the verge of abandoning the scheme after becoming exasperated with the local council and Health and Social Care Partnership."Im at the end of my tether with it now," she said. "Im seriously just thinking about selling the land. It did have planning permission before for  large houses, so that could go ahead instead.": Rural care homes closing amid staffing and costs struggleBute has one of the oldest populations in Scotland and high rates of dementia.However, it has only one residential care facility - eight-bed council-owned Thomson Court - which caters to people with dementia, learning disabilities, young people with support needs and frail older adults.A larger care home for older people, privately-run Craigard in Rothesay, was forced to shut down in  after the Care Inspectorate said residents were at "high risk" of harm.As a result many families are left to cope with relatives with dementia at home, or face sending them miles away to a mainland care home.Mrs Woollcott has worked with architects GD Lodge and experts in dementia services from Stirling University to design a purpose-built retirement village comprising  bungalows and a -bed nursing home with specialist dementia facilities, en-suite rooms, gardens, a hairdressers and restaurant.While the demand is there, she says the couple are fearful of investing in the development without a guarantee - or letter of comfort - from the authorities that they will actually send local people to the facility.: People with dementia should get free care like anyone  with a progressive illnessMrs Woollcott previously owned a small private care home on Bute during the s, but said it had been forced to close after the then-Strathclyde council prioritised its own homes for referrals.She said: "They sayI build it theyll use it, but my healthcare consultant is saying well, would you spend pound million building something without any sort of guarantee "This is what happened on Bute before. I had a nursing home, and there was another huge nursing home on the front too."We were all put out of business at that time because they had a huge annex on the hospital, and people who had chosen to come into my home or the other nursing home would be talked round to staying there instead, or told there would be more trained staff in the local authority home."I just need a guarantee that,we build it, they will use it."The project has previously been backed by Bute community council and by local MSP, Mike Russell, who said the present need to send people to the mainland for care was "bad for the iniduals, the families involved and not positive for the island itself".Mrs Woollcott says she has written to Prince Charles, the Duke of Rothesay, asking for his help.She said: "Our old people are suffering and have been for years. I know elderly people who have to travel on the ferry every day, in all weathers, taking buses and taxis, just so that they can visit their husband or we on the mainland."Ive got a friend whose mum and dad have both got dementia but theyre both at home because she doesnt want to have to send them away. Its traumatic.": A vision for dementia care in ScotlandBob Wade, , looked after his we Margaret for  years until his frailty and her worsening dementia forced him to place her in a care home on the mainland, in Port Glasgow, in August .Mr Wade, a retired Ministry of Defence worker, who had lived on Bute with his we, , since , said it was now "very dficult" making the journey via taxi and ferry to visit Margaret because he has broken both his legs in recent years and walks with a frame."Im . With crutches it was hard, but with the frame now its just impossible," said Mr Ward.A relative, who has recently retired to Bute and owns a car, now drives Mr Ward once a fortnight to Port Glasgow, helping him on and off the ferry.He said having a facility like Ascog Park on the island would have made a big dference.Mr Wade said: "It would have helped enormously. I read a couple of years back in the Buteman that there wasnt a requirement for a care home on Bute - it strikes me thats just an excuse to save money."I understand that islands tend to have more older people and it is dficult for the council to justy setting up, in a small community, a home big enough to accommodate all those people who need it."But heres someone offering to build it."An Argyll and Bute HSCP has previously said it ldquowould not be appropriate to guarantee referrals to Ascog Park because it is for families and not the HSCP to decide on the preferred home for their relative.A spokesman was unable to respond when asked to comment on the current situation.

title: conservatives-accuse-snp-sabotaging-brexit
story: UK Government insiders believe the First Minister and her colleagues are deploying a deliberate strategy to ldquodisrupt Brexit preparations north of the border in the hope that this will boost the campaign for Scottish independence.The claims come after Edinburgh has received nearly pound million from the Treasury, money Whitehall believes should be spent specically on preparing Scotland for Brexit. But UK ministers and officials suspect much of the money has not been used for the purpose they insist it is intended.A senior UK Government source told The Herald: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos accounting is opaque to say the least. Without greater clarity, the suspicion will be that they are not serious about preparing for Brexit.ldquoWhile apparently opposing no-deal they have consistently refused to support a deal. It really does look asthey are hoping for a disruptive Brexit in the belief it would drive support for independence. They need to prepare for Brexit, not prepare for a blame game.One example given was how the Scottish Government was failing to hand over allocated money to local councils so that enough staff could be employed to provide the health certicates that will be needed for Scottish fish exporters to send their produce to the continent post a no-deal Brexit.If the export of perishable fish products from Scotland were disrupted, it is feared restaurants and food outlets such as in France, the Benelux countries and Spain would seek out other producers, which could have a devastating impact on Scotlandrsquos important fishing industry, threatening jobs and livelihoods.David Duguid, the Conservative MP for Banff and Buchan, said he had for months been in contact with local and central government about preparations for a no-deal Brexit but feared not enough was being done in Scotland.He referred to how in February it was announced more than poundm was being made available to the Scottish Government to prepare but ldquonot a penny had made its way to the local authorities.But in the spring, Michael Russell, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Constitutional Relations Secretary, insisted the money had been ldquodistributed across the portfolios and was being used across the public sector.Mr Duguid told The Herald: ldquoIrsquom in favour of a deal, the UK Government is in favour of a deal but we still have to be prepared for a no-deal.ldquoMy fear is that, should there be a no-deal Brexit, the Scottish Government have not done their jobhellipI hope they are not playing silly games, allowing the fishing industry to fail. What would they saythe rest of the UK was prepared for no-deal and they werenrsquot Askedhe felt the SNP administration was deliberately trying to cause disruption over Brexit to further the independence cause, Mr Duguid replied:ldquoThere is always a suspicion the SNP will use anything to pump up the cause of independence. I hope that is not the case.Meanwhile, a UK Government spokeswoman explained: ldquoThe Scottish Government have received almost poundm in funding for EU exit preparation. It is the responsibility of the Scottish Government to decide where this money is spent to ensure Scotland is prepared for leaving the EU on October .ldquoAdditionally, all three devolved administrations can bid for[money from] the Operational Contingency Fund of poundbn, where they face disproportionate pressures to England.In July, Scottish Labour accused Derek Mackay, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Finance Secretary, of ldquoblowing a hole in Scotlandrsquos Brexit preparations after it was revealed, at the time, that of the pound. million allocated for them in  , Edinburgh had spent around poundm on other things.Of the pound.m allocated for  , UK Government officials say there appear to be no details of expenditure. ldquoThey canrsquot say how they spent it, noted one.Thus far, the Scottish Governmentrsquos extra funds allocated on the back of the UK Governmentrsquos spending on Brexit have been: pound.m in   pound.m in   pound.m for   announced in February and .m also for   announced in August. This brings the total to pound.m.In addition, the Scottish Government has asked for poundm from the contingency fund for Brexit preparations to cover, among other things, support for rural communities in the event of a no-deal outcome, Police Scotland activities, additional communication to EU citizens and poverty mitigation measures.A UK Government spokesman said Edinburghrsquos request would be considered in the ldquousual way. If granted, this would, according to the Treasuryrsquos view, mean the Scottish Government will have received more than poundm for Brexit preparations.Thus far, the UK Exchequer has, overall, made more than poundbn available to prepare for Brexit since the  referendum, including pound.bn specically for no-deal planning.However, funds have been handed over to the Scottish Government via the Barnett Formula, which allocates a proportionate share of departmental spending increases and decreases made in England to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland based on population share.Crucially, while the UK Government might want Edinburgh to spend the money for the same purpose it is being used in England, the Scottish Government is entitled to spend it how it likes.A spokesman for Mr Russell said: "These are gobsmacking comments from the Tories. Scotland did not vote for Brexit and we should not be having to spend a single penny on Brexit preparations ndash this is similar to an arsonist setting fire to someonersquos house and then complaining about the fire servicersquos efforts to extinguish the blaze.ldquoThe fact is, the Scottish Government has allocated proportionately the same Brexit preparation funding to local authorities as the UK Government from the consequentials received to date. Local authorities can submit further funding requests for EU exit costs through the submission of a business case. This process has been put in place for all public sector bodies ndash and local government are not being treated dferently.ldquoVirtually all of the pound.m in consequentials we have received from the UK Government have been allocated ndash but even then, the true cost of Brexit is expected to far exceed this amount. We should not have to cut spending on public services to fund the Tory Brexit obsession.

title: pictures-thousands-independence-supporters-march-edinburgh
story: Organisers of All Under One Bannerevent in Edinburgh confirmed that Saturdayrsquos demonstration was the biggest one yet, estimating that over , people took part.Men, women, children and pets were draped in Saltires, waving flags, bagpipes and lsquoYesrsquo banners as they walked from Holyrood Park to the Meadows.The First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was absent during the march but took to Twitter to tell supporters that she was there lsquoin spiritrsquo.:Everything you need to know about All Under One Banner march in Edinburgh on SaturdayShe said: ldquoGood luck to everyone marching for independence in Edinburgh later. Irsquom not able to be there in person today, but I will be with you in spirit.ldquoHave a great day. And be in no doubt - independence is coming. #indyref.Those who took part in the march were met with a small counter protest that carried Union Jack flags. There was a heavy police presence on the Royal Mile as they walked by and no one was hurt.AUOB organisers printed , new flyers for the event and  Yes Bikers lead the march with bagpipers in tow.:All Under One Banner submit plans for  Scottish independence march in GlasgowSNP MP Joanna Cherry spoke to the massive crowd that gathered in the Meadows after the march.She said: ldquoIndependence is coming soon.In the current form of British politics, itrsquos hard just to see when and where the opportunity will arise, but it will arise, and we have to be ready for it.ldquoSo, my question to you today is are you ready  You look pretty ready to me.Although Scots voted to stay part of the UK by % to % in the  referendum, latest poll figures suggest that support for independence rises to % for and % against.

title: syndrome-society-children-daydream-class-naughty-can-diagnosed-adhd
story: Smith, author of "Hyperactive: The Controversial History of ADHD" said: "Rather than questioning why children are naughty or daydream in class, naughtiness and daydreaming are seen as symptoms of ADHD."It is much easier to blame the child and label them as dferent or abnormal than it is to adapt classroom environments in ways that are more accommodating for children who find it dficult to pay attention or to resist the urge to misbehave."Blaming a glitch in the brain is also easier than looking for other potential triggers for such behaviour, such as problems at home, lack of physical activity or time spent outdoors, too much screen time or even reactions to food chemicals."Research has also shown that the children who tend to be diagnosed with ADHD are usually the youngest in their class cohort, meaning that simply may be less mature than their older classmates."We need to be think of these things first before diagnosing a child with ADHD and prescribing stimulant drugs."

title: saving-scotlands-rivers-people-bringing-ravaged-waterways-back-life
story: Downstream energy: The people bringing our ravaged rivers back to leThe new Rock Ramp at Howden Weir in Livingston tuesday, the largest of its kind ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtin the UK helping filtspan classtruncate-full-screengtsh upstream.Pic Gordon Terris The HeraldEncased in concrete and hidden from view for over  years, an entire generation has grown up alongside one of Glasgowrsquos rivers without ever seeing it.Now a major project to revitalise Tollcross Burn in the cityrsquos East End is set to begin, alongside work to improve dozens of other Scottish rivers, many of which had been sacriced in the name of progress and development.In some cases, the enhancement and restoration works will helplong-lost fish and other wildle to waterways left almost bereft of le because of manmade structures, industrial and agricultural pollution.Most will see rivers once considered little more than a dirty blot on the landscape reborn to become a thriving artery at the heart of communities.Some % of Scotlandrsquos  rivers are classed by environmental regulator SEPA as falling below good standard with concerns over poor water quality, physical condition and habitat.Of that number, around % ndash equating to some  rivers ndash have been identied as having been adversely affected by manmade alterations such as weirs, culverts and barriers which negatively impacted on fish migration and in some cases raised the risk of flooding.The pound. million Tollcross project is among  river improvement schemes currently being carried out by SEPA in tandem with local authorities and other partners under the Scottish Governmentrsquos Water Environment Fund.The fund, which has received poundm from the Scottish Government since , aims to rejuvenate and repair damaged rivers, improve water quality, enhance the natural environment for local communities and improve fish stocks by removing barriers that have closed rivers to migrating fish for generations.It has already helped revitalise rivers across Scotland, among them a barren stretch of South Calder Water within the Stane Gardens area of Shotts in North Lanarkshire.Shunned by locals for years as an ugly and unpleasant eyesore and with the river re-routed through an open concrete drain, it is now an attractive watercourse with gentle meanders and rippling flows. The surrounding wasteland has also been transformed into a landscaped valley featuring paths and sculptures which recognise the arearsquos industrial heritage.Other projects have included the creation of the UKrsquos largest rock ramp, a fish ladder which connects the lower and upper reaches of the River Almond at Howden Bridge Weir in West Lothian. Opened last month, it allows fish to travel upstream for the first time in over  years and is one of a series of projects which has opened km of river to migratory fish species and improved overall river quality.The Tollcross Burn project will restore a section of the previously covered waterway which was culverted through Sandyhills Park in the s to make way for a now demolished housing project.Work will start this month to remove it from its concrete case, so it can once again become a focal point for park visitors, stimulate bioersity and also provide natural flood prevention.Francis Hayes, SEPArsquos WEF Restoration Specialist, said: ldquoIn terms of what you can do to a river, putting it in a concrete pipe and burying it is the worst.ldquoTollcross Burn was culverted in s and erted. Since then, people have been living next to a river but had no idea it was there, they werenrsquot able to see it or enjoy it.ldquoAs a river, itrsquos dead, he added. ldquoFish donrsquot like to travel in dark spaces and canrsquot go up a smooth concrete channel, therersquos no habitat for insects that are vital for river wildle and no light. So itrsquos very dficult for animals and plants to survive.ldquoWe want to make it a living, thriving river.The improvements, which are being carried out in partnership with Glasgow City Council and have received pound.m funding from Glasgow and Clyde Valley City Deal, will introduce a new -metre open channel which will follow the original course of the burn.As well as improving the natural surroundings, it will help reduce the flood risk caused by the climate emergency and extend the arearsquos sewage capacity. There are also plans to restore and tackle historically contaminated ground in the area.At the same time, work is set to start on measures tomigrating fish to Garrell Burn beside the Dumbreck Marsh nature reserve at Kilsyth.The burn was canalised and while the previously industrial area has now developed into a valued wetland used by runners, walkers, cyclists, pet owners, children and commuters, manmade structures prevent fish from migrating.Work will be carried out by SEPA, North Lanarkshire Council and Scottish Water to naturalise the river, helping to restore flood plains and create fish passes.Dozens of river improvement projects, many of which remove barriers that prevent fish from accessing spawning areas and raised the risk of flooding, have been carried out since the Fund was introduced in .They include work at Gottar Water Weir at Quarrierrsquos Village, Kilmacolm in Renfrewshire, where a post-industrial weir had blocked access to km of habitat for migratory fish species such as Atlantic salmon, sea trout and eel for over a century.The existing weir is to be partly lowered, increasing the downstream water level and improving the water quality, as well as providing new community leisure opportunities.Mr Hayes said there are hopes that improvement works can be carried out at most ndashnot all ndash of the  rivers negatively affected by manmade structures before .The improvement works could help correct two centuries of damage to Scotlandrsquos rivers caused by industrial and urban growth.Prior to the rapid growth of industry and urbanisation of the s, Scotlandrsquos rivers were regarded as being of very good quality. However, river quality deteriorated throughout the th and th centuries, largely due to the discharge of sewage, and agricultural and industrial pollution, and manmade efforts to alter their course which have led to the loss of habitat and prevented fish migration.Since , the Water Environment Fund has helped open up more than km of rivers to salmon and other fish species, while flood prevention work has also been carried out to help make rivers more resilient to the impact of the climate emergency.One of the largest projects is an ambitious partnership plan to revitalise the River Leven, West Dunbartonshire, and turn land which once housed several hundred mills and factories into a lsquogo-torsquo leisure and tourism destination.The project includes removing barriers to fish migration and improving water quality.Mr Hayes said: ldquoPeople were smart in the past but they had dferent information and dferent knowledge from today and we are suffering from that legacy.ldquoRoads, services and railways were being built and rivers were seen as an inconvenience. They were pushed out of the way and then it was a case of lsquoout of sight out of mindrsquo.ldquoWe have damaged rivers and blocked them off to fish. We donrsquot want to hand that legacy to the next generation, so we are trying to do something about it.ldquoBy pulling resources and sharing expertise we can bring a better landscape in often deprived areas. If we restore a river it becomes a nice, natural place people want to be in, it promotes sustainable transport with cycleways and itrsquos a good thing for health and well-being.

title: seeds-change-gardening-saving-peoples-lives
story: The wind was howling and in one of the worst snowstorms in living memory, Francesca Rychel left home without her winter coat and vanished into the wild blizzard.It would take several hours and the efforts of mountain rescue teams and snfer dogs to find her on a nearby hillside, severely hypothermic and barely alive.She woke in hospital days later, furious. ldquoI was angry, she recalls. ldquoI didnrsquot want to be there having to deal with things.ldquoI was so low, I didnrsquot get out of bed. I wasnrsquot eating or drinking. Visitors brought me nice things but I didnrsquot want them. I turned my face to the wall. I didnrsquot want to be there.Tormented by complex post-traumatic stress disorderlinked to childhood experiences, it would not be counselling or modern medicine that would boost her recovery.Instead, remarkably, it would be a packet of seeds, a flowerpot and a handful of potting compost. Left by her bed by a thoughtful nurse, the simple act of planting the seeds and watching them grow would become her motivation to slowly get better.Today, mother-of-two Fran, , is among the volunteers at Space to Grow, a therapeutic garden a stonersquos throw from the Huntlyburn mental health unit at Borders General Hospital in Melrose, which is gently nurturing green shoots of recovery from vulnerable and frail patients.Originally an acre of forgotten land battling against waist-high brambles and choking weeds, it has been coaxed into le by patients, volunteers and staff to become a busy allotment where cheerful flowers bloom and a healthy crop of runner beans, squash, tomatoes, potatoes, courgettes, cucumber and herbs thrive. The therapeutic gardening it provides is increasingly recognised as delivering a range of health benefits, from boosting physical and mental health, to promoting conversation and stimulating thinking skills.In recent years, hundreds of small therapeutic gardens and community allotments have sprung up across the country. Most are manned by devoted volunteers who tease overgrown and unloved land into vegetable plots, mini orchards, flower beds, and where potting sheds double as a focal point for socialising and cups of tea.According to Fiona Thackeray of gardening charity Trellis, which provides guidance and support for almost  therapeutic gardening projects across Scotland, new ones are springing up at an average of one every week.ldquoWhen we first started the charity  years ago, people would look at me a little askance when I mentioned the therapeutic impact of gardening, she says. ldquoBut the evidence has built up such a lot since then.ldquoWe now have up to  new garden projects coming to us every year looking for help and support.ldquoThese gardens are helping people to meet other people, recover from severe mental illnesses, get back to work, regain their motivation and receive support.Some gardens provide a space for refugees to share support and discover what kinds of plants, fruits and vegetables they can grow on Scottish soil.Some in the grounds of nursing homes provide gentle activity for residents with dementia, while community gardens lure lonely people from home to meet new friends. Others encourage addicts to find solace in nature or provide calm space for cancer, heart attack or stroke patients.For Fran, the small packet of seeds, flowerpot and soil left by Jan Moffat, the mental health nurse who developed Borders Hospitalrsquos Space to Grow garden, would be le-changing.ldquoJan brought in a packet of seeds, soil and the plant pot and just left them at my bedside table. I stared at them for a week, then one day decided to plant the seeds.ldquoThat meant I had to get up to get water for them. When they got too big for the pot, I had to get dressed and repot them down in the greenhouse. It meant I had a reason to get up. Then I had to eat because I needed the energy to do what I wanted in the garden. I started to re-engage with le.It was, she adds, ldquotransformational.ldquoI now feel like myself for the first time in  years, she says. ldquoIrsquom working full time and Irsquom able to do more with my children. Without the garden, I might not be here at all.Jan Moffat, meanwhile, has seen the garden bring a range of benefits, from the patient who uses it as a peaceful spot to meditate to another who suffered agitated outbursts but now works off excess energy in the garden.ldquoFor some itrsquos a break from boredom of the ward, she adds, ldquowhile for others that link from nature gives them some respite from how they feel.There are hopes the garden will eventually provide similar therapeutic benefits to other hospital patients in the future.Similar therapy gardens are thriving across the country. At Silverburn Park in Leven, Fe. work is under way to turn a B-listed former flax mill and gardens into a ldquoCentre for Wellbeing while Trellis fieldworkers are supporting volunteers in a revitalised walled garden and sensory garden.In Paisley, a therapeutic garden is supporting ex-offenders, and in North Ayrshire another provides therapy for head injury patients.In West Dunbartonshire, the Leamy Foundation gardens are helping to combat the loneliness and isolation that can lead to depression and anxiety. As well as boosting mood and self-esteem, they are teaching new skills and helping children understand the links between food, waste and nature.Launched after a consultation with local foodbanks revealed around one-third of people attending identied as having mental health concerns, it has led to self-managed gardens popping up on spare plots of land in Alexandria housing estates and in raised beds at St Mungorsquos Episcopal Church, where kale, sweetcorn, tomatoes, herbs and potatoes are growing alongside apple and plum trees and strawberries.A partnership with West Dunbartonshire Council led to a network of community garden and allotment groups, while the foundation has also helped an addiction service launch a therapeutic garden of its own.ldquoWe saw the isolation, anxiety and depression, says project development manager Kevin Mason.ldquoWe wanted to give people of all ages the chance to get out of the house and speak to people about how they are getting on, to share positive things in their lives and help each other.The impact has been ldquoincredible, he adds. ldquoPeople have been helped to move on with their lives and go back into employment because their confidence has grown.ldquoSome of the first people who came to us are now with us as volunteers and helping others.ldquoWersquore giving people a reason to come out and get involved in their community, he adds.ldquoThey enjoy the peace and quiet and the chance to lose themselves in the act of growing something.

title: first-woman-climb-every-mountain-scotland-ireland-plans-final-ascent
story: Her feet ached, she was cold, wet and had trouble walking for days afterwards.Once the discomfort passed however, the -year-old felt an incredible sense of achievement and a calmness that she found boosted her mood.It was that feeling of wellbeing that encouraged her to try again ... and again ... almost every month for the past  years.Next week she is set to become the first woman in the UK to have climbed all  mountains over ft in Scotland and Ireland, and will raise money for Scottish Mountain Rescue during her final trek.Grandmother-of-two Christine, from Carstairs, said: ldquoI never expected to have done so many walks but I just love it.ldquoI enjoy going with friends, but I also like being out on the hills on my own. The feeling of getting to the top, and the views you get to see, are just incredible.While the sense of achievement reaching a new summit is one of the reasons Christine loves the hobby, it is the feeling of perspective and wellbeing which she enjoys most of all.ldquoThere have been times, not often, when Irsquove felt down and I havenrsquot been looking forward to a walk, she said.ldquo I think lsquowould I rather be in tears at the bottom of a mountain or at the top rsquo. The thing is, once you get to the top the problems and worries are gone. It puts everything into perspective.ldquoI lived in London for a while and every weekend Irsquod come back and get out on the hills. It was such a sense of relaxation and calm compared to a busy city. Irsquod be on a mountain in the morning and by the evening Irsquod be on the sleeper train.Social worker Christine has chosen to raise money for Scottish Mountain Rescue as she has seen how important their role is in keeping people safe.While she has never needed rescued herself, she has had friends airlted to safety after getting into trouble. Tragically another of her friends also died while out walking and his body was retrieved by the mountain rescue crew and ed to his loved ones.She said: ldquoThey do such an important job, and they make walking safe for people like me. Even though Irsquove never needed to use them, the knowledge that they are theresomething goes wrong is reassuring.ldquoWhile mountains are amazing to climb, people often underestimate how dangerous it can beyou are not prepared orthe weather changes. Thatrsquos why Scottish Mountain Rescue is so important, and why I wanted to help.Along with the many friends she has made along the way, Christine said she has had incredible experiences during many of her  walks.One of the highlights was when she scaled the notorious Inaccessible Pinnacle on Skye. Standing at the top, she saw a double Brocken Spectre - a ghostly vision resembling something from a supernatural film.ldquoIt looks like a wee alien, surrounded by this big circle of light. You can only see your own, nobody rsquos. Irsquove seen them before but this was just incredible, after trying so hard to get up the Inaccessible Pinnacle, to see a double Brocken Spectre was something . Irsquoll never forget that day.To donate to Christinersquos fundraiser for Scottish Mountain Rescue, visit https:www.justgiving fundraising mylastftmountainChristinersquos top  mountain walks in Scotland: Bidean nam Bian, Glen Coe Braeriach, Cairngorms Inaccesible Pinnacle, Isle of Skye Suilven, Sutherland Aonach Eagach, Glen Coe

title: andrew-marr-ridge-sunday-sunday-politics-scotland-review
story: ldquoSomething big is going to happen in the next few weeks, said Sophy Ridge. ldquoWe just donrsquot quite know what yet.Andrew Marr wonderedNumber rsquos ldquocunning plan was to pretend they had one.On Sunday Politics Scotland, Gordon Brewer also askedthe Government had a ldquocunning plan to circumvent the Benn Act that requires it to seek a delay to Brexit in the event of no deal.Lots of questions, but as for answers they were harder to come by than an apology from Donald Trump. The only sure bet on Sunday mornings is that a husk of hares will be set running by the papers said Lepus europaeus will then be chased by the TV shows who will in turn hand the matter on to those lucky enough to be putting together Mondayrsquos papers. Think of it as the circle of le, media-style.Yesterdayrsquos chief hares included John Bercow being in the running to head a caretaker government, and Boris Johnson planning to barricade himself inside Downing Streethe lost a vote of no confidence.: Davidson unlikely to stand at electionMarr, wisely, turned to a voice of reason from Europe, and few come across as more level-headed than Krisjanis Karins, the Prime Minister of Latvia. Calm, reassuring, the soul of clarity, one cannot help but think that negotiations would have been in a better place nowthe US-born former businessman had been in charge. But there were limits to even Mr Karinsrsquo patience. Describing the UK Governmentrsquos proposal as a basis for negotiation, he added thatthe offer turned out to be ldquotake it or leave it then that would be ldquovery dficult .Next contestant to play the speculation game with Marr was Shami Chakrabarti, the Shadow Attorney General. As all those with a Higher in Sunday morning shows will be aware, the encounters between Marr and the Baroness are not always plain sailing. Turn to page  of your textbook for an account of the great squall of November  Labourrsquos Brexit stance even though she had voted Remain. ldquoI donrsquot know about you, Andrew, but Irsquom a democrat. Marr barked back: ldquoDonrsquot try and patronise me. Irsquom as much a democrat as you are. Comedy gold.All was calm yesterday, with Ms Chakrabarti assuring viewers that there was no loophole in the Benn Act through which the PM could wriggle. Asked about arrangements to have ABJas caretaker PM, she would not be drawn. Bercow  Kenneth Clarke  ldquoWersquore now getting into almost fantasy football, she said of the names being mooted as team manager.If anyone was going to have some answers on Brexit it would be the man with the word in his job title, right  Wrong. Stephen Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, had dropped in on his way to Amsterdam, part of a whirlwind tour of European capitals this week. Is there a cunning plan regarding the Benn Act, asked Marr, and do you know what it is  ldquoThere are ious iables that may happen, said Mr Barclay, generously. Would anyone bring some Rumsfeldian clarity to the matter : Indy supporters on marchOn Sunday Politics Scotland, Ian Blackford, SNP leader in Westminster, had a go. Like Baroness Chakrabarti, he reckoned the Benn Act was pretty watertight, dismissing Downing Street mutterings as ldquobluff and bluster. ldquoWersquove gamed out all of this, he went on. Presenter Gordon Brewer, while acknowledging Mr Blackford was keen to stay ldquosecret squirrel on the oppositionrsquos plans, pressed him further. Aside from some bluster on the MPrsquos own part about seizing control of the Commons agenda ndash as had been done to bring about the Benn Act ndash details were there none.The Liberal Democrat MP Christine Jardine was askedthere was a cunning plan on the Governmentrsquos part or, Brewer added, even a rubbish one  Downing Streetrsquos plans thus far, the presenter said, had turned rather ldquoBaldricky, ie fallen apart on contact with reality.that adjective now, Mr Brewer, it will make you a fortune.Ah, Blackadder and Baldrick, who knows what you would have made of Brexit. You may recallthe poignant ending to the brilliant tale of Edmund Blackadder and his trusty,not very bright, servant.It is  and Blackadderrsquos company is about to go over the top. The battlefield guns fall silent. Maybe the war is over, Baldrick speculates, maybe it is peace. It is not.Baldrick says he has a plan. A cunning and subtle one.ldquoAs cunning as a fox who has just been appointed Professor of Cunning at Oxford University  inquires Captain Blackadder. Alas it is too late, and Blackadderrsquos final words ring out: ldquoGood luck everyone.Before we go, brief mention in dispatches for Sophy Ridge, who went to Boris Johnsons constituency of Uxbridge and South Ruislip for a vox pop. ldquoDonrsquot you even mention that name in front of me, that filthy piece of toerag, said a shopper. I now declare the  Brenda From Bristol Award for Plain Speaking officially open.

title: tributes-wild-volatile-cream-drummer-ginger-baker
story: Cream drummer Ginger Baker is credited with helping to define the psychedelic rock sound of the s and s and widely regarded as one of the best drummers the British music scene has ever witnessed.However, the iconic rocker - who died on Sunday at the age of  - was also known for his violent outbursts with bandmates, failed relationships and rude and obnoxious personality.His family confirmed the London-born starrsquos death on social media yesterday, after revealing last month that he was critically ill in hospital.His daughter, Nettie Baker, said her father died peacefully and without pain.A statement on Twitter said: ldquoWe are very sad to say that Ginger has passed away peacefully in hospital this morning. Thank you to everyone for your kind words over the past weeks.Baker is also survived by son Kofi and daughter Leda.Many paid tribute to the musician on social media, with Paul McCartney posting on Twitter: ldquoGinger Baker, great drummer, wild and lovely guy. We worked together on the lsquoBand on the Runrsquo album in his ARC Studio, Lagos, Nigeria. Sad to hear that he died but the memories never will.Psychedelic rock band Hawkwind, who worked with Baker, also tweeted their condolences.ldquoFly high Ginger! You were a one off and and a true legend...We were honoured to work with you...RIP, the band stated.Many fans also paid tribute.Born in Lewisham in , Baker began drumming in his mid teens after sitting down at a drumkit and discovering instantly that he could play.He formed the influential group Cream with Jack Bruce and Eric Clapton in  and went on to drive a change in rock music which would later pave the way for groups such as Led Zeppelin.The drummerrsquos groundbreaking style combined jazz with a heavy, hard-hitting sound and helped to build the bandrsquos unique profile and devoted following.One of rockrsquos first ldquosupergroups, songs like Strange Brew, Sunshine of Your Love, Badge and I Feel Free contributed to the triorsquos popularity.They sold more than  million albums and were awarded the worldrsquos first ever platinum disc for their LP Wheels of Fire.Speaking previously about his time with Cream, Baker said: ldquoIt was assomething  had taken over. Yoursquore not conscious of playing.ldquoYoursquore listening to this fantastic sound that yoursquore a part of. And your part is justhellip happening. It was a gt, and we three had it in abundance.An inductee in the Rock And Roll Hall Of Fame, Bakerrsquos rampant solo performances with Cream also helped to raise the profile of drummers in rock music.However, the relationships between the musicians werevolatile and their arguments frequent and violent.The band eventually split after two years and four albums, with a farewell concert at Londonrsquos Royal Albert Hall in .After Cream came the short-lived Blind Faith, working again with Clapton, along with Steve Winwood.Unconventionally, the drummer then moved to Lagos to pursue an interest in African music, working with jazz powerhouse Fela Kuti.In his book, Hellraiser: The Autobiography Of The Worldrsquos Greatest Drummer, Baker chronicled his long-lasting drug habits, which included heroin and cocaine.His confrontational side was also captured in the documentary Beware Of Mr Baker, which showed him fighting with the filmrsquos director.In the opening scene, the musician was seen attacking director Jay Bulger with a metal cane, declaring: ldquoIrsquom going to put you in hospital.He later settled down to reluctantly reflect on the trail of broken bands, ex-wives and neglected children hersquod left in his wake.Those interviewed marvelled at his talent, but little , with one contributor, Freersquos Simon Kirke, who toured with Cream, saying: ldquoHe influenced me as a drummer, but not as a person.Baker later reconciled with Clapton again in , although a Cream reunion was ruled out due to disagreements between the drummer and Bruce.He suffered heart complaints in later le, writing on his personal blog in : ldquoJust seen doctorhellip big shockhellip no more gigs for this old drummerhellip everything is offhellip of all things I never thought it would be my heart.

title: research-lead-jury-trial-shake
story: The findings of the research are expected to lead to a consultation on whether to scrap the lsquothirdrsquo verdict, leaving juries the option of just guilty or not guilty. Ministers have been pressed to drop the lsquonot provenrsquo option, notoriously described by Sir Walter Scott as lsquothat bastard verdictrsquo. The then Scottish justice Secretary Michael Matheson commissioned the research from Glasgow and Warwick universities two years ago in response to recommendations made by Lord Bonomy in a review of the safeguards neededcorroboration were to be scrapped.It has seen hundreds of members of the public serving on mock juries, and has taken evidence from more than  jurors, in one of the biggest enquiries into the jury system ever in the UK.
